description: A vine species of passion flower native to southern Brazil through Paraguay and northern Argentina. It is cultivated commercially in tropical and subtropical areas for its sweet, seedy fruit.
seasons: Varies by region, can fruit year-round in some tropical climates
healthBenefits: Rich in dietary fiber, promoting digestive health and regularity.
Good source of Vitamin C and Vitamin A, supporting immune function and vision.
Contains antioxidants that help combat free radicals.
May have calming effects and aid in sleep due to certain compounds.

potentialAllergies.name: Passion Fruit Allergy
potentialAllergies.details: Allergies are uncommon but can occur.

cultivationProcess:
Step-by-Step Growing Guide:
1. Climate: Tropical and subtropical. Some varieties tolerate cooler conditions.
2. Soil: Well-drained, fertile soil rich in organic matter. pH 6.5-7.5.
3. Propagation: Seeds or cuttings.
4. Planting: Plant in full sun against a trellis, fence, or arbor for support as it's a vigorous vine.
5. Watering: Requires regular watering, especially during flowering and fruiting.
6. Fertilizing: Feed regularly with a balanced fertilizer during the growing season.
7. Pollination: Some varieties are self-pollinating; others require cross-pollination or hand pollination.
8. Harvesting: Fruits drop from the vine when ripe or can be picked when they change color (purple or yellow, depending on variety) and become slightly wrinkled.
growthDuration: Vines can start fruiting within 6-12 months from planting. Fruits mature in 70-80 days after pollination.
sustainabilityTips: Store passion fruit at room temperature until wrinkled (indicating ripeness), then refrigerate.
Pulp can be scooped out and eaten fresh, added to drinks, or used in desserts.
carbonFootprintInfo: Moderate to high if air-freighted from distant tropical regions (0.8-2.5 kg CO2e/kg).

staticRecipes.name: Fresh Passion Fruit Pulp
staticRecipes.description: The simplest way to enjoy the intense, aromatic flavor of passion fruit.
steps: Cut the fruit in half crosswise.
Use a spoon to scoop out the aromatic, jelly-like pulp along with the edible black seeds.
The pulp can be eaten directly, seeds and all. It's tangy, sweet, and highly flavorful. Often used as a topping for yogurt, ice cream, or desserts.

staticRecipes.name: Passion Fruit Juice/Cooler
staticRecipes.description: A refreshing tropical drink bursting with flavor.
ingredients: 2-4 tbsp sugar or simple syrup (to taste)
steps: Scoop the pulp from the passion fruits into a blender or a bowl.

If using a blender, add a little water and pulse a few times briefly just to loosen the pulp from the seeds (don't over-blend or you'll crush the seeds too much). If not using a blender, mash the pulp with a fork in a bowl with a little water.
Strain the mixture through a fine-mesh sieve into a pitcher, pressing down on the pulp to extract as much juice as possible. Discard the seeds and membrane caught in the sieve.
Add the remaining cold/sparkling water and sugar/simple syrup to the pitcher. Stir well until the sweetener is dissolved.
Taste and adjust sweetness. Serve chilled over ice, garnished with a mint sprig if desired.

staticRecipes.name: Passion Fruit Mousse
staticRecipes.description: A light and airy dessert with the exotic taste of passion fruit.
ingredients: 1/2 cup passion fruit pulp (seeds strained if preferred)
1 tsp gelatin dissolved in 2 tbsp hot water (or agar-agar for vegetarian)
Optional: extra passion fruit pulp for topping
steps: If using gelatin, dissolve it in hot water and let it cool slightly. If using agar-agar, prepare according to package instructions with a little liquid and heat.
In a chilled bowl, whip the heavy cream with powdered sugar until soft peaks form.
Gently fold the passion fruit pulp into the whipped cream.
If using gelatin/agar-agar, gently fold the cooled (but still liquid) mixture into the cream and passion fruit mixture until just combined.
Spoon the mousse into individual serving glasses or a larger bowl.
Chill in the refrigerator for at least 2-3 hours, or until set.
Serve chilled, optionally topped with a drizzle of fresh passion fruit pulp.
